item.title: MacRitchie Reservoir
item.description: Background information Address: MacRitchie Reservoir Park, Singapore 298717 11km of walking trail How I got there Took bus 855 to Opp…
item.content:encoded:
Background information

  • Address: MacRitchie Reservoir Park, Singapore 298717
  • 11km of walking trail

How I got there

Took bus 855 to Opp Macritchie Reservoir bus stop.

My route

Started from near the bus stop and then also ended at the bus stop (actually forgot to stop the tracking at the bus stop itself so the final part included a small bit of the bus ride back home)

Unfortunately, TreeTop Walk is closed until next year.

I’ve been here twice, but during the first trip, I just did a round trip between the starting place and Jelutong Tower. The second trip covers the entire MacRitchie Nature Trial.

Photos shown here were taken from the first trip though, as I didn’t take any during the second trip.

Link to walking route map

The experience

Wow, 11km is really no joke (at least for unhealthy old me). Anyway, the path starts off like any park as usual, with all the nice greenery.

After a short walk, the path splits between Chemperai Boardwalk and Lornie Trail. In my first trip, I got to experience both ways because of the round trip. For the second trip, I took the Chemperai Boardwalk to avoid the muddy path.

This is how Lornie Trail looked like - a very pleasant walk while enjoying the shelter provided by the trees. The muddy road was not pleasant though.

After that, it was just a straight and long path next to Singapore Island Country Club.

Finally reached Jelutong Tower, which was another simply tower for observation. It has more stories so it was more tiring to climb to the top, and I wouldn’t say that the view is that great either to be honest.

Then, it was just continuing the rest of the path, passing by the closed TreeTop Walk. There’s a ranger station too for a quick toilet break or refilling your water bottle.

item.title: The Southern Ridges
item.description: Background information Opening hours: 0700 - 1900 10 km of green, open spaces that connect Mount Faber Park, Telok Blangah Hill Park…
item.content:encoded:
Background information

  • Opening hours: 0700 - 1900
  • 10 km of green, open spaces that connect Mount Faber Park, Telok Blangah Hill Park, HortPark, Kent Ridge Park and Labrador Nature Reserve

How I got there

Took MRT to one-north station, but you can start from Kent Ridge MRT.

My route

Started somewhere near one-north MRT and ended when I entered Vivocity.

Basically took Route A (but starting from Kent Ridge), which did not cover Labrador Nature Reserve.

Link to walking route map

The experience

First, we walked through Kent Ridge Park. I think I might have missed the Canopy Walk by taking the wrong path though, but oh well.

I crossed this cool looking overhead bridge which I think should be the Alexandra Arch.

There was also the Forest Walk which was really nice, as the entire pathway is like elevated above the forest. Stupid me forgot to take a photo.

Then, it was just back to the ground with a huge open space. Lots of different flowers and plants were being grown at the sides and there were some glasshouse looking structures as well.

Next, I crossed the even more spectacular Henderson Waves. The bridge was super wide and you can stop to enjoy the breathtaking view.

Finally, we entered Mount Faber Park. Was tempted to take the cable car, but decided to walk the final part of the path left and made it to Vivocity!

item.title: Sungei Buloh Wetland Reserve
item.description: Background information Address: 301 Neo Tiew Crescent, Singapore 718925 Opening hours: 0700 - 1900 Park Size: 202 hectares How I got there…
item.content:encoded:
Background information

  • Address: 301 Neo Tiew Crescent, Singapore 718925
  • Opening hours: 0700 - 1900
  • Park Size: 202 hectares

How I got there

Took a taxi from Yew Tee MRT, but you can take bus 925M near Kranji MRT station.

My route

Only started the tracking at Fantail Pod and ended when we exited the place from the Wetland Centre.

Link to walking route map

The experience

The place feels more suited for a slow, leisurely walk. You can easily cover the whole place in a much shorter time, since I stopped multiple times to enjoy the view of nature.

There was this path which we walked by, but it was closed off due to the flood. Not sure if this path is always like this?

There’s quite a number of spots meant for birdwatching and stuff, but all I had was a normal camera.

For wildlife, we saw crocodiles, monkeys, birds. The big prize goes to this giant komodo dragon(?) just chilling on the path.

You can climb this Aerie Tower for a better view of the place. It’s only a few stories tall.
